awd_titl_txt: Resuscitation and assembly of the rhizosphere microbiome in response to plant stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants associate closely with some soil microorganisms and engage with them in beneficial relationships near the root surface. It is expected that beneficial microbes can support plants to be resilient to stresses in the environment, such as drought. However, it is not well understood how microbes are recruited to the root during stress or which members of the diverse soil microbial community are most responsive during stress. This research will investigate how microorganisms respond to plant hormones that signal stress. Understanding the dynamic relationships between soil microbes and plants during stress is important for anticipating, and potentially managing, expected changes in plant performance given environmental and land-use changes. This project will assess how soil microorganisms alter their growth and activities when exposed to plant hormones, quantify how the molecules released from roots change during stress and assess the responses of microbes to those changes, and determine how members of soil microbial communities collectively respond to plant stress signals in natural and controlled environments. This work has broad significance for understanding plant resilience, with expected outcomes of national interest for agriculture and land management, food and energy security, sustainability, and general soil health. It will also benefit society by providing quantitative scientific workforce training and community outreach at Michigan State University's Science Festival and other public campus events.  

The objective of the research is to understand the rules of assembly and function of the rhizosphere microbiome given exposure to plant hormones that signal stress. For plants, root microbiome recruitment and assembly is facilitated through the soil, which provides the physical, chemical, and biological context for plant-microbiome engagement. Soil harbors a rich reservoir of microbial diversity, but up to 80% of microorganisms in soil are dormant and have inaccessible functional potential. When plants are stressed, they release metabolites into the soil that could serve as signals to microorganisms. This research aims to: 1) uncover bacterial responses in growth and resuscitation to stress phytohormones; 2) to quantify microbial community dynamics and interactions given plant stress signals; and 3) to identify members of complex soil microbial communities that resuscitate and assemble to the rhizosphere during stress. A multi-scale approach will be used that combines in vivo quantification of bacterial responses to phytohormones, synthetic microbiome construction and manipulation, and in situ experiments of rhizosphere microbiome dynamics in soil. This research is expected to decipher rules governing microbiome dynamics when plants are stressed. A foundational understanding of the interactions between plants, microorganisms and the environment will facilitate management of microbiomes towards desired functions, and will support goals towards sustainable agriculture and food and energy security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview
Like humans and other living organisms, plants form intimate relationships with a community of associated microorganisms called the microbiome. These microbial communities are responsive to plant signals, are sensitive and dynamic to changes in the environment and plant development, and many are expected to provide some benefit to their host. However, the mechanisms that drive plant-microbiome interactions remain unclear, especially when the plant is experiencing stress.

Microbiome members are dynamic in their activities and can assume a state of inactivity for prolonged periods.  This research aimed to understand better the activity dynamics of root-associated microbiome resuscitation and subsequent recruitment to the rhizosphere when plants are stressed. The project?s approach integrated across scales, including molecules, microorganisms, communities, and plant systems, and applied an ecological framework.

Intellectual Merit
The overarching objective of this award was to understand the rules of assembly and function of the rhizosphere microbiome, given exposure to plant stress signals. To achieve this objective, we performed experiments supporting two specific aims.  

The first major Aim was to uncover bacterial growth and reactivation responses to plant stress signals (phytohormones). We found that different environmental bacterial strains exhibited different growth dynamics in the presence of phytohormones compared to control growth:  some had growth increases in the presence of phytohormones, some had decreased, and some had no response. The exposure concentrations of the phytohormone were also relevant, with some bacteria exhibiting a threshold response in their growth changes while others indicated a gradient response. Different groups of environmental bacterial strains that were phytopathogens, plant-associated, or bulk-soil-associated were not discriminated by shared responses to phytohormones. These results suggest a complicated interplay between plant stress and the microbiome that can be investigated further to determine the situations and qualities that permit beneficial plant outcomes enabled by the microbiome during stress exposure.

The second major Aim was to identify members of complex soil microbial communities that reactivate and assemble to the rhizosphere during drought stress. In these experiments, we compared the responses for common bean, an annual legume crop, and switchgrass, a perennial grass targeted as a biofuel feedstock. We examined drought and well-watered conditions for the first experiment, with and without the plant in the soil. We found that each plant harbored a different active microbiome but that drought dynamics (changes in the microbiome) were comparable across plants, with increasing drought severity. The host influenced the response of the rhizosphere microbiome to drought in the case of bean plants but not switchgrass.   We also identified several bacterial taxa uniquely activated with the plant during drought, suggesting selection by both the host and the environmental changes attributed to drought. We examined active microbiome responses to phytohormone exposure in the rhizosphere soil for the second experiment. We found a robust bacterial responder to abscisic acid, a phytohormone made by plants during drought. This body of work suggests new directions to advance understanding and development of tailored bacterial microbiome solutions are required for each crop, as we did not observe any universally responsive bacteria to drought across these two crops.  

Broader Impacts
Understanding interactions between a microbiome, its host, and the environment is expected to facilitate the prediction, management, and remodeling of microbiomes toward desired functions. In the case of plant-associated microbiomes, this foundational knowledge can be leveraged to conceive of and test new bioinoculation or other field management interventions to support crop production and stress tolerance.  

This award contributed to the scientific training and workforce development of three undergraduate researchers, one post-baccalaureate researcher, two master's students, one doctoral student, five post-doctoral researchers, and one research technician. These project personnel contributed to the scientific communication and valorization of the work by presenting their results in scientific posters, seminars, and conference presentations. The results of this research have been prepared for publication in peer-reviewed journals and as a master's thesis.   

This project has contributed to the societal goal of open and reproducible science. Bioinformatic and statistical analysis code associated with this work are available on GitHub. The data are deposited in the NCBI sequence read archive (PRJNA862978 and PRJNA932434).
